newsitem.title: CHINA: China to cut international phone call fees.
newsitem.headline: China to cut international phone call fees.

text.p: China said on Saturday it would cut the cost of international telephone calls by an average of 30 percent but raise the price of local phone calls by 20 percent.
The cost of mailing a domestic letter would jump as much as 400 percent with all of the new rates going into effect on Sunday, the official Xinhua news agency said.
Excessively high international charges were seriously affecting China's international telephone business while local phone calls were set too low, resulting in losses, according to the news agency.

The cost of a telephone call from Beijing to the United States would be cut to 21 yuan ($2.53) per minute from 26.25 yuan now while the cost of a call to Japan would fall to 14.50 yuan per minute from 18.15 yuan.
China is facing increased competition from so-called 'call back' services which allow customers to make payments overseas and take advantage of usually lower foreign rates.
The price of a local phone call in Beijing would climb considerably more than the average, rising 44 percent to 0.18 yuan per minute from 0.125 now, according to local telephone authorities.
The Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications would reduce telephone installation fees and telephone service fees for rural areas, Xinhua said.
It also called for an end to "excessive charges" set on top of official rates for telephone services by hotels, guest houses and office buildings.

The basic cost of mailing a domestic letter would rise to a flat 0.5 yuan from a range of 0.1 to 0.2 yuan currently. The post office would still be losing money as the average cost of delivering a letter was 0.89 yuan, according to the news agency. ($1 = 8.3 yuan)
